results.title: La Bamba
results.creator_credit: Columbia, New Visions Pictures, Taylor Hackford and Luis Valdez
results.brief_description: Musical biography of Ritchie Valens, a poor Mexican-American who became a rock’n’roll sensation at age 17 in the 1950’s. Lou Diamond Phillips portrays Valens whose musical career ended when he was killed in the plane crash that also claimed the life of Buddy Holly. The music of Valens is performed by Los Lobos on the soundtrack.

results.title: La Balance (S)
results.creator_credit: Les Film Ariane, Films A2 and Bob Swaim
results.brief_description: Heightened crime and increased prosititution in the streets of Paris, force the criminal investigation department to set up a special unit of police called the Territorial Brigades. Their only hope of penetrating the French Maffia is through a network of informers but the perfect informer is killed and another must be found from the pimps and prostitutes of the French underground. Voted the best film of the year in France at the time of its release, La Balance is a world of violence where only the tough survive. This version is dubbed in English.

results.title: La Baie des Anges = Bay of Angels
results.brief_description:
An ordinary bank clerk who has had a streak of good luck at the Nice casino, falls in love with a compulsive gambler, who has left a husband and child to satisfy her craving. Shot very quickly on the French Riviera, this love story with a roulette wheel as the motif and the motive, is one of the most vivid evocations of gambling fever on film. The luminous photography and the hypnotic music add to the film’s attraction. Reference: Bloomsbury Foreign Film Guide.

Credits: Producer, Paul-Edmond Decharme ; director, Jacques Demy ; writer, Jacques Demy ; photography, Jean Rabier ; music, Michel Legrand, art direction, Bernard Evein.
Cast: Jeanne Moreau, Claude Mann, Paul Guers.

results.title: L.S. Lowry
results.brief_description: The work of L.S. Lowry, a Manchester-born artist, who has lived and worked in that area all his life. He has been described as an English ‘primitive’, but he is first and foremost a painter closely related to the world he knows. Shows many examples of his painting and reveals much of the artist’s personality and his relationship to his work.

results.title: L.I.E. = LIE [DVD]
results.creator_credit: Alter Ego, Belladonna, Linda Moran, Rene Bastian and Michael Cuesta
results.brief_description: Writer/director Michael Cuesta’s feature film debut deals with the difficult, often emotive, subject of paedophilia with compassion and sensitivity combined with an air of realism and awareness of teenage sexuality and the complexities of life that often face young male adolescents as they forge their way into adulthood. L.I.E., which stands for Long Island Expressway, is a symbolic reminder to 15 year-old Howie (Paul Franklin Dano) who has recently lost his mother through a car accident on the L.I.E. and is struggling to cope emotionally with her loss. His father Marty (Bruce Altman) who finds solace in a shallow based-on-sex relationship with his new girlfriend is also on the run from the law through his corrupt business practices and barely has time for his lonely grieving son. Disillusioned and confused, Howie forms a bond with three rather rebellious and streetwise dysfunctionals who spend more time out of school than in, robbing local houses to finance their habits. The relationship between Howie, and Gary (Billy Kay), who unbeknownst to Howie sometimes works as a male prostitute, evolves into something beyond friendship, causing Howie to reflect on his sexuality and his feelings towards Gary. But the issue of Howie’s sexuality soon takes another path when through one of his robbery escapades with Gary, he meets middle-aged ex-marine “Big John” Harrigan (Brian Cox) - a regular customer of Gary’s who has a penchant for boys in their early teens. When Gary runs off to California, and his father is arrested by the FBI, Howie finds an unexpected degree of emotional support in his relationship with the rather curious and compassionate paedophile who seemingly understands Howie’s tenuous and helpless situation. A very moving story with moments of warmth and humour but which also delves into the murkier side of urban life and paedophilia. In the director’s words “It was vital the audience could relate to Big John, even sympathise with him, but I tried very hard to make sure his intentions were constantly blurred”. Superb cinemaphotography by Romeo Tirone and outstanding performances by the lead actors, makes this multi-award winning film compelling viewing, both emotionally and psychologically. (Awards: Edinburgh 2001, Stockholm 2001, Independent Spirit Awards 2002) [End of file]

results.title: L.A.: as suggested by the art of Edward Ruscha
results.creator_credit: Gary Conklin Films and Gary Conklin
results.brief_description: Edward Ruscha’s paintings, drawings and photographs are the point of departure for this impressionistic study of Los Angeles’ buildings, apartment houses, palm trees, swimming pools, cars and signs, enhanced by the city’s unique winter light. Features music by Gershwin, Django Reinhardt, Eric Satie, Czerny, M. Lecudna. Suitable for middle and upper secondary levels.

results.title: L.A. Story
results.creator_credit: Daniel Melnick, Indieprod, L. A. Films and Mick Jackson
results.brief_description: Steve Martin wrote this romantic comedy, in which he stars as Harris K. Telemacher, a Los Angeles wacky weatherman extraordinaire. After growing increasingly distanced from his socialite girlfriend Trudi (Marilu Henner) and unhappy with his job, he finds his spirit renewed by the arrival of a British journalist (Victoria Tennant). An oddball, but very amusing look at the faux pas and foibles of life in modern Los Angeles.

results.title: L.A. confidential [DVD]
results.creator_credit: Regency Enterprises, Arnon Milchan, Curtis Hanson and Michael Nathanson
results.brief_description: Based on a James Ellroy novel, ‘L.A. Confidential’ perfectly recreates the mythology of film noir embedded within the city of Los Angeles circa 1950. Stylishly melding real and imagined Hollywood and crime folklore, the complex plot involves hookers that are made up to look like movie stars, corrupt cops on the take, sleazy tabloid journalists and of course, murder. Russell Crowe is excellent as the brutish but honest cop who teams up with an opportunistic rookie (Guy Pearce), and a smooth, star struck police officer (Kevin Spacey), to solve the gang style murder of a group of innocent bystanders in a late night diner. The investigation uncovers a sinister web of blackmail, sex and greed, implicating some of the upper echelons of L.A. society. No noir film would be complete without the obligatory femme fatale, played with sultry poise by Kim Basinger who won an Oscar for her performance. Rather than it being mere pastiche, director Curtis Hanson treats the material in a direct, earnest fashion and in doing so delivers one of the best examples of the genre for some time. Cast also includes Danny DeVito, David Strathairn and James Cromwell.

results.title: L'une et L'autre = the Other One
results.brief_description:
A young actress, with a rather fragile personality, borrows her sister’s identity in order to break-up with her current lover.

Credits: Producer, Nicole Stephane ; director, Rene Allio ; writers, Rene Allio, Gerard Pollicand ; photography, Jean Badal ; music, Serge Gainsbourg.
Cast: Philippe Noiret, Claude Dauphin, Malka Ribowska, Francoise Prevost, Christian Alers.

results.title: L'Orfeo
results.brief_description: This opera, sung in Italian, was written by Claudio Monteverdi under the commission of the Duke of Mantua, who wanted the legend of Orfeo, revived in the previous century, set to music. Monteverdi combines dramatic tension, eloquent expression of human passions and formal variety in his setting of Alessandro Stiggio’s libretto. The direction, staging and design is by Jean-Pierre Ponnelle. Features singers Pillippe Huttenlocher (Orfeo), Dietlinde Turban (Euridice), Trudeliese Schmidt (Musica/Speranza), Roland Hermann (Apollo), Glenys Linos (Proserpina), Werner Groschel (Plutone), Hans Franzen (Caronte), Suzanne Calabro (Ninfa) and the Monteverdi Ensemble of the Zurich Opera House conducted by Nikolaus Harnoncourt. No English subtitles.
